title: 113_s2077
content: The "Emergency Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2014" includes provisions for extending the emergency unemployment compensation program, temporary extension of extended benefit provisions, funding for reemployment services, additional extended benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act, flexibility for unemployment program agreements, and offset from farm bill savings. The Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program is extended until July 1, 2014, with funding amendments. The effective date for these changes is retroactive to the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EXTENSION OF EXTENDED BENEFIT PROVISIONS. The text extends various unemployment benefit provisions, changing deadlines from December 31, 2013, to June 30, 2014, and then to December 31, 2014. The text extends unemployment benefit provisions, changing deadlines to June 30, 2014, and aligning with the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. The text extends funding for reemployment services and eligibility assessment activities through the first half of fiscal year 2015. Additionally, it provides additional extended unemployment benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to extend benefits until June 30, 2014. Funds can be used for extended benefits and administration costs. The Railroad Retirement Board is appropriated $125,000 for administrative expenses related to extended unemployment benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act amendments. SEC. 6. FLEXIBILITY FOR UNEMPLOYMENT PROGRAM AGREEMENTS. Flexibility is granted to States regarding unemployment program agreements. States that have enacted a law before December 1, 2013, which would violate a specific subsection, are exempt from it. This exemption applies to weeks of unemployment starting on or after December 29, 2013. Additionally, States whose agreement under the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 was terminated can enter into a subsequent agreement if they meet the requirements, considering the aforementioned exemption. SEC. 7. OFFSET FROM FARM BILL SAVINGS. The term "farm bill savings" refers to budgetary effects attributable to the Agricultural Act of 2014. The Office of Management and Budget and the Senate Budget Committee are required to remove these savings from their PAYGO scorecards. The budgetary effects of the Agricultural Act of 2014, known as "farm bill savings," must be removed from PAYGO scorecards. This Act specifies that these savings cannot be used to offset the costs of other legislation under the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 or section 201 of S. Con. Res. 21. Additionally, the budgetary effects of this Act and its amendments will not be entered on PAYGO scorecards maintained under the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 or for purposes of section 201 of S. Con. Res. 21.
